channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Activist Is Arrested
item.description: Prosecutors said that they had arrested a former member of a defunct party on suspicion of breaking an anti-communist law with comments about North Korea.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Memo From China: Exploring a New Role: Peacemaker in Afghanistan
item.description: Beijing, with political and financial interests, overcomes a longstanding reluctance to get involved in regional conflicts.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping, right, of China, with Afghanistan’s president, Ashraf Ghani, at a ceremony in October outside the Great Hall of the People in Beijing.

item.title: World Briefing: C.D.C. Chief ‘Confident’ on Ebola
item.description: The director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said Tuesday that the Ebola outbreak in West Africa could be brought under control.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Nigeria: United Nations Calls for an Inquiry
item.description: The U.N. called on Nigeria on Tuesday to restore law and order in its northeast and to investigate mass killings of civilians said to have been carried out by Boko Haram insurgents.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Britain: Blair Defends I.R.A. Deal
item.description: Mr. Blair on Tuesday defended his government’s decision to give Irish Republican Army fugitives written assurances that they would not be arrested, and denied keeping the deal secret.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Ex-Marine Says Iranians Want a Swap to Free Him
item.description: The family of the former Marine, Amir Hekmati, has been receiving telephone calls and emails from Iran proposing prisoner swaps for Iranians held in the United States, he said in a letter to Iran’s president.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: Amir Hekmati, shown in an undated photo, has been incarcerated for three years.

item.title: Europe Focuses on Emerging Threats From Smaller Crews of Terrorists
item.description: European leaders have begun looking for ways, including enhanced surveillance powers, to prevent violence from militants acting virtually alone.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Anger at Officials’ Expensive Meal Before Deadly Shanghai Stampede
item.description: Public outrage is mounting amid reports that local leaders dined at an expensive Japanese restaurant as 36 people died on New Year’s Eve amid lax security and crowd control.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: The mother of a victim cries on Jan. 2 at the spot where 36 people died in a stampede during a New Year's Eve celebration on the Bund in Shanghai.

item.title: Newspaper in Israel Scrubs Women From a Photo of Paris Unity Rally
item.description: The publication generally avoids running pictures of women for reasons of modesty, and its intended audience has been known to scratch female faces out of bus advertisements.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: An altered photograph by the ultra-Orthodox Jewish newspaper HaMevaser removed the images of Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany and other female leaders.

item.title: France Mourns Attack Victims and Takes Steps Against Further Terrorism
item.description: Three coffins draped in the French tricolor were laid out in Paris as tribute was paid to the officers who died. In Jerusalem, four other victims were buried.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL and MAÏA de la BAUME

item.title: Charlie Hebdo’s Defiant Muhammad Cover Fuels Debate on Free Speech
item.description: Six days after the attack on Charlie Hebdo, Muslim groups in France, Egypt and elsewhere said the newspaper’s new cover would exacerbate tensions.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Egyptian Judge Voids Mubarak’s Last Standing Conviction and Orders Retrial
item.description: But even before the ruling, former President Hosni Mubarak had already spent enough time in detention to allow his release for time served.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Islam’s Problem With Blasphemy
item.description: Muslims should simply ignore insults to their faith, the Quran says.
item.dc:creator: By MUSTAFA AKYOL

item.title: New Charlie Hebdo Cover Creates New Questions for U.S. News Media
item.description: The cartoon depiction of Muhammad on Charlie Hebdo’s new cover has presented another editorial judgment to news media about whether to republish it.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE and RAVI SOMAIYA

item.title: 10 Are Killed in Ukraine as Diplomacy Hits a Wall
item.description: A shell or rocket that appeared to be aimed at an army checkpoint in southeastern Ukraine hit a bus. The episode came as plans for a peace summit meeting collapsed.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH

item.title: State in India Plans to Help Gay Youth ‘Get Over Same-Sex Feelings’
item.description: The state of Goa in India, where homosexual relations are illegal, plans to treat teenagers who say they are gay, bisexual or transgender with programs that include counseling.
item.dc:creator: By SUHASINI RAJ and NIDA NAJAR

item.title: Francesco Rosi, Italian Filmmaker With Political Bent, Dies at 92
item.description: Mr. Rosi’s commitment to social issues made him a direct heir to the traditions of Italian neorealist cinema of the postwar years.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN ANDERSON
item.media:description: Francesco Rosi in Paris on the set of his movie “Carmen” in 1984, played an instrumental part in the highly politicized post-neorealist Italian cinema of the 1960s and ’70s.

item.title: Syria Peace Hopes Dim Further as Opposition Rejects Moscow Talks
item.description: Russia has been working to persuade both sides to attend preliminary talks, but in recent days, several opposition figures said they would not attend.
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Alibaba Will Help Curb Export of Recalled Items
item.description: The Chinese e-commerce group has agreed to prevent the export of dangerous items recalled by the Consumer Product Safety Commission.
item.dc:creator: By PAUL MOZUR
item.media:description: An Alibaba warehouse. The company is teaming with American safety regulators.

item.title: Senior Rebel From Uganda to Be Moved to the Hague
item.description: Dominic Ongwen, a commander with the Lord’s Resistance Army, led by the fugitive Joseph Kony, was detained by American Special Forces last week.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By JEFFREY GETTLEMAN
item.media:description: Dominic Ongwen was detained by American Special Forces last week, officials said.
